Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Understanding on the Role of Structural Defects on Lithiation of Nanoscale Transition Metal Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non Technical Abstract
Extensive research worldwide is underway to find better materials for Li-ion batteries in order to increase their energy and power. Transition metal oxides offer superior performance as electrodes for lithium-ion batteries; however, the progress toward their commercial use has been hindered due to lack of understanding of their electrochemical performance. In particular, variations in local atomic structure and chemistry need to be better investigated in order to properly design them for rechargeable battery applications. With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, this project will work to address this shortcoming. The principal investigator plans to study the electrochemical battery reactions inside high-resolution electron microscopes enabling imaging down to atomic level. With this capability, lithium-ion movements inside the battery electrodes can be investigated in the presence of structural defects.

Technical Abstract
Nanoscale transition metal oxides (TMO) are promising materials for lithium-ion batteries. These materials operate through conversion reactions and are associated with high energy densities. These materials are highly vulnerable to structural defects produced during synthesis that can alter lithium ion pathways and affect their electrochemical performance. The objective of this research activity is to understand the underlying atomistic mechanisms by which structural defects such as heterointerfaces and dislocations affect the lithiation behavior of TMOs. To meet this goal, nanoscale TMOs are subjected to real time electrochemical lithiation inside atomic-resolution transmission electron microscopes. This project is expected to yield better understanding on the evolution of localized strain and electronic structure at the vicinity of structural defects and their effect on lithium-ion pathways. In addition, the structural evolution of conversion reaction phases can be investigated in the presence of heterointerfaces and dislocations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome Summary

The goal of this project was to understand the underlying mechanisms of transition-metal based electrode materials for batteries and the role of structural heterogeneities on their electrochemical behavior. We reported several new phenomena including (1) the asynchronous lattice expansion in MnO2 nanowires; (2) the role of twin boundaries on lithium ion transport; (3) the effect of tunnel stabilizer K+ cations in MnO2 and their interaction with Li ions; (4) continuum-based modeling of anisotropic diffusion of lithium ions in SnO2 materials; (5) atomic-scale understanding of transition in layered MnO2 materials to tunnel-based materials; (6) the effect of tunnel size and tunnel heterogeneities in MnO2 materials on ion diffusion; (7) a mutual energy-driven

mechanism that dominated the evolution of the crystal facets in both beta-MnO2 nanowire and microstructures; (8) new synthesis method for chemical mixing transition metal oxides, and (7) mechanisms of volume expansion in Cu2O nanowires during lithiation/delithiation.  

Intellectual Merit

Utilizing in-situ electrochemical testing in TEM resulted in several important discoveries in various metal oxide materials including MnO2, V2O5, Cu2O, and SnO2 nanowires. We investigated the role of tunnel cations in governing the electrochemical properties of electrode materials by focusing on K+ in α-MnO2. Interestingly, MnO2 materials undergo asynchronous lattice expansion upon lithiation. Both self-growth and oriented attachment along their {100} facets were observed as two different ways to reduce the surface energies of the beta-MnO2 structures. We showed that the presence of K+ inside 2×2 tunnels of α-MnO2 nanowires increased the electronic conductivity, and improved Li+ diffusivity. We also revealed the role of twin boundary defects during the lithiation of SnO2 metal oxides. Our atomic-resolution TEM results show that twin boundaries are preferable pathways for lithium ions. Using in-situ TEM we demonstrated that copper oxide/carbon-nitride core–shell nanostructures accommodate the volume change during lithiation-delithiation processes. Our results suggest that the pristine V2O5 nanowire forms a Li oxide shell which then acts as a solid state electrolyte to conduct Li+ ions and bulk of the V2O5 nanowire undergoes transformation to the  phase. Also Joule-heating synthesis method enabled a new paradigm in development of high entropy metal oxide nanoparticles.

Broader Impact

Our findings on nanoscale electrochemical behavior of transition metal oxide materials provide a more accurate view to the behavior of these high capacity materials for lithium-ion batteries. More than 12 PhD students and postdocs were trained on various aspects of materials research, electrochemistry, and electron microscopy techniques. We collaborated with more than 20 research groups and research institutions to address the research questions and underlying mechanisms by working on this award. Undergraduate students visited our laboratory and learned about the on-going research on battery materials. Total PhD dissertation supported by this project was 3. The results of this project award are published in 37 peer-reviewed journal articles, 1 book chapter, and 3 PhD thesis. More than 30 conference presentations were delivered by the PI and his PhD students at national and international conferences. Multiple press releases disseminated the major contributions of this project to the public. Two graduate level courses were developed with emphasis to the research activities of this award and several other lectures were given in the undergraduate and graduate classrooms to stimulate the interests of students on the importance of nanoscale electrochemistry in order to address the materials challenges of energy storage systems. Several outreach lectures and lab demos were conducted for high-school students and freshman undergraduate students. Four female students were recruited and participated on the research activities of this award.
